clinical_study.brief_title: Postoperative Epidural Analgesia in Spine Fusion Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Postoperative Epidural Analgesia in Spine Fusion Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: we aim to compare the analgesic effect of 0.125% bupivacaine HCL, 0.125% bupivacaine HCL + Morphine sulphate 3 mg, 0.125% bupivacaine HCL + Fentanyl 100 micro gram both at rest and mobilization maneuvers.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Caregiver, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.description: â€¢ Pain will be assessed using the VAS ranging from "0" (no pain) to "10" (worst imaginable pain). Pain will be evaluated at rest, while coughing, and during mobilization. Maneuvers of particular clinical importance for postoperative mobilization (alone and with help) will be chosen: Turning in bed, standing in front of the bed and walking, and using the toilet without help. The time needed until the patient can first successfully perform these maneuvers will be documented.

secondary_outcome.description: verbal rating score will be used (4 = very satisfied, 3 = satisfied, 2 = neutral, 1 = dissatisfied, and 0 = very dissatisfied).

other_outcome.description: 3 serum samples for beta-endorphin will be taken 1st one preoperative base line , 2nd at VAS more than 3 at rest ,3rd when VAS less than 2 at rest

arm_group.description: 0.125% Bupivacaine HCL , Morphine sulphate 3 mg @ 3-5 ml/h

intervention.intervention_name: 0.125% Bupivacaine HCL , Morphine sulphate @ 3 mg 3-5 ml/h

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients undergoing spine fusion surgery.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Drug addiction. Intraoperative dural tear. Uses of opioids drug for any reason in the previous 48 hours. Mental dysfunction. Spinal fusion for any infectious or malignant causes.
